- **Governance:** Compliance with 2024 Corporate Governance Regulations required
- **Source:** BoU/UMRA regulatory framework

---

### RWANDA

#### Tax Regime
- **Corporate Tax Rate:** 28% (effective September 14, 2024 onwards; previously 30% for income up to September 13, 2024)
  - **Pro-Rata 2024:** 30% (Jan 1 - Sep 13), 28% (Sep 14 - Dec 31)
  - **Medium-Term Target:** 20% corporate tax rate
- **Micro-Enterprises (<RWF 12M turnover):** Flat tax amounts based on turnover
- **Small Businesses (RWF 12M - 20M turnover):** 3% lump sum tax on turnover
- **Deposit-Taking Microfinance Institutions (Competent Authority Approved):** 0% CIT for 5 years from approval
- **Financial Services (Registered Investors):** 15% preferential CIT rate for global business, private equity funds, fund management, wealth management, mutual funds, collective investment schemes, captive insurance, venture capital, asset-backed securities
- **VAT Rate:** 18% standard rate
- **VAT Exemptions:** Clean water, health goods/services, educational materials/services, transport (except land), books/newspapers/journals, financial and insurance services, land/building leases for residential purposes
- **VAT Registration Threshold:** RWF 20 million annual taxable turnover OR RWF 5 million in a calendar quarter
- **Withholding Tax:** 15% on dividends, financial interest, royalties, repatriated profits, etc.; 5% on imported goods for commercial use; 3% on public tender winners (15% if not registered with tax admin or no prior tax declaration)
- **Tax Clearance Certificate Benefit:** Businesses with certificate exempted from all WHT deductions
- **Gaming WHT:** 15% on difference between winnings and stake
- **Source:** [Rwanda Tax Guide 2024](https://www.hlbrwanda.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/HLB-Rwanda-2024-Tax-Guide-2_240925_210103.pdf), [Rwanda Corporate Tax PWC](https://taxsummaries.pwc.com/rwanda/corporate/taxes-on-corporate-income)

#### Central Bank Circulars & Regulations
- **Regulatory Authority:** National Bank of Rwanda (BNR)
- **Historical Licensing Framework (2008):**
  - **Commercial Banks:** RWF 5 billion minimum paid-up capital
  - **Microfinance Banks:** RWF 1.5 billion minimum paid-up capital
  - **Development Banks:** RWF 3 billion minimum paid-up capital
  - **Source:** [BNR Licensing Changes 2018](https://en.igihe.com/news/bnr-introduces-changes-in-licensing-requirements)

- **2018 Regulatory Changes:**
  - **Commercial Banks:** RWF 20 billion paid-up capital (NEW)
  - **Development Banks:** RWF 50 billion paid-up capital (NEW)
  - **Cooperative Banks (NEW category):** RWF 10 billion paid-up capital
  - **Mortgage Banks (NEW category):** RWF 10 billion paid-up capital
  - **Transition Period:** 5 years to build capital (RWF 15 billion by year 3, full RWF 20 billion by year 5)
  - **Source:** [UNCTAD Rwanda Central Bank Requirements](https://investmentpolicy.unctad.org/investment-policy-monitor/measures/3344/rwanda-central-bank-introduces-new-requirements-for-licensing-financial-institutions)

- **Current Status (2023-2025):**
  - **Banking Sector Composition (Dec 2023):** 9 commercial banks, 3 microfinance banks, 1 development bank, 1 cooperative bank
  - **Anticipated Changes:** Three microfinance banks expected to transition from bank category to MFI category to comply with new capital requirements
  - **Foreign Presence Requirement:** Approximately $20 million minimum share capital to establish banking presence in Rwanda
  - **Capital Adequacy (2025):** Banks 20.5% (above 15% minimum), MFIs 32.3% (above 15% minimum)
  - **Source:** [Rwanda Monetary Policy March 2024](https://www.bnr.rw/documents/MPFSS_March_2024_Final_Booklet.pdf), [Rwanda Monetary Policy March 2025](https://www.bnr.rw/documents/MPFSS_Report_March_2025.pdf)

#### Licensing Requirements
- **Application:** Submit to National Bank of Rwanda with business model demonstrating market gap
- **Capital:** Approximately $20 million minimum share capital for banks
- **Business Model:** Must demonstrate gap in market
- **Microfinance Institutions:** Capital requirements distinct from microfinance banks (specific amounts require direct BNR consultation)
- **Source:** [BNR Licensing Requirements](https://www.bnr.rw/financial-stability/microfinance-institutions/licensing-and-approval-requirements/)

---

## TIER 4: EGYPT, MOROCCO (NORTH AFRICA)

### EGYPT

#### Tax Regime
- **Corporate Tax Rate:** 22.5% flat rate on net taxable income (applies to all businesses including foreign-owned companies, LLCs, branches)
- **VAT Rate:** 14% standard rate
- **Reduced VAT (5%):** Machinery and equipment for manufacturing and service provision (payment suspended on imported or locally purchased items)
- **VAT Registration Threshold:** EGP 500,000 annual turnover
- **Zero-Rated VAT:** Exports of goods/services, goods/services from free zones
- **Withholding Tax:** 20% standard rate
  - **Interest on Loans (Private Sector):** Exempt if >3 years; 20% WHT if <3 years
  - **Royalty Payments:** 20% WHT
  - **Treaty Reductions:** 65+ treaties; most reduce interest WHT to 15%, royalties to 5-15% (from 20%)
- **Stamp Tax:** Two types - nominal (e.g., EGP 1 per contract paper) and proportional (0.05%-0.3% based on transaction value)
- **Bank Loan Stamp Tax:** 0.4% annual proportional stamp tax (shared by bank and client)
- **Source:** [Egypt Tax System GSL](https://gsl.org/en/taxes/egypt/), [Egypt Corporate Tax PWC](https://taxsummaries.pwc.com/egypt/corporate/taxes-on-corporate-income)

#### Central Bank Circulars & Regulations
- **Regulatory Framework:** Dual regulation by Financial Regulatory Authority (FRA) and Central Bank of Egypt (CBE)
- **Primary Microfinance Regulator:** FRA under Microfinance Law No. 141 of 2014 (+ amendments)

- **Capital Requirements:**
  - **Non-Banking Fintech Entities (Microfinance under FRA):**
    - **Start-ups (Temporary 2-year license):** EGP 15 million for some activities (less stringent)
    - **Established Market Players:** EGP 75 million for some activities
  - **CBE Payment Service Providers (Category-Based):**
    - **Category A PSPs:** EGP 30 million minimum capital
    - **Category B PSPs:** EGP 10 million minimum capital
    - **Account Information/Payment Initiation Service Providers:** EGP 20 million minimum capital
  - **Digital Banks (for context):** EGP 4 billion issued and fully paid-up capital (or USD 120 million for foreign bank digital branches)
  - **Grace Period (PSPs):** 12 months for existing payment institutions to comply with new rules
  - **Source:** [Egypt Fintech 2024](https://practiceguides.chambers.com/practice-guides/fintech-2024/egypt), [CBE Payment System Rules 2025](https://www.cbe.org.eg/en/news-publications/news/2025/06/19/08/20/psos-and-psps-licensing-rules)

- **CBE Requirements for Microlending:**
  - **Electronic Payment License:** Required from CBE for fintech entities in micro-lending
  - **Credit Inquiry Contract:** Must have contract with CBE-licensed credit inquiry company
  - **Federation Membership:** Must join Egyptian Federation for Financing Medium, Small and Micro Enterprises
  - **Source:** [Microlending Egypt Compliance Guide](https://eg.andersen.com/microlending-in-egypt/)

- **Data Requirements (2024):**
  - **NDPC Guidance (Feb 2024):** Entities processing data for >200 individuals in 6 months OR operating in finance, healthcare, education sectors qualify as Data Controllers and Processors of Major Importance (DCPMIs)
  - **African Union Convention:** Nigeria signed AU Convention on Cybersecurity and Personal Data Protection (Jan 2024) - includes data rights, security, enforcement provisions
  - **Source:** [CBE Digital Banks Framework](https://www.tamimi.com/news/the-central-bank-of-egypt-introduces-the-regulatory-framework-and-licensing-requirements-for-digital-banks/)

#### Licensing Requirements
- **FRA License:** Required for microfinance services; demonstrate capital adequacy, consumer protection, operational guidelines compliance
- **CBE License:** Electronic payment solutions license required for micro-lending fintech entities
- **Application:** Submit to FRA with compliance documentation
- **Capital:** EGP 15 million (start-ups) to EGP 75 million (established players) for fintech microfinance
- **Source:** FRA and CBE regulatory framework

---

### MOROCCO

#### Tax Regime
- **Corporate Tax Rate:** 35% for companies with net tax income ≥ MAD 100 million
  - **Reduced Rate:** 20% if net profit below MAD 100 million for 3 consecutive years
  - **Phased Implementation:** Target rates 20%/35% fully applicable January 2026 (progressive 2023-2026)
- **VAT Standard Rate:** 20%
- **VAT Reduced Rate:** 10% for banking/credit services, leasing, gas, water, electricity
- **VAT for Insurance Agents/Brokers:** 14% (being phased out in 2024 reforms)
- **VAT Transition (2024-2026):** Gradual transition to 0%, 10%, 20% rates only
- **Withholding Tax:**
  - **Dividends (Resident Company):** NOT subject to WHT
  - **Dividends (Resident Individual):** 12.5%
  - **Dividends (Non-Resident):** 10%
  - **Interest (Resident Company):** 20%
  - **Interest (Resident Individual):** 30%
  - **Interest (Non-Resident Loan):** 10% (unless reduced by treaty)
  - **Interest (Non-Resident Loan ≥10 years):** EXEMPT
  - **Royalties (Resident):** EXEMPT
  - **Royalties (Non-Resident):** 10%
- **Branch Tax:** 15% on net income transferred to foreign entities
- **VAT Withholding (2024 New Measure - Effective July 1, 2024):**
  - **Rate:** 75% of VAT withheld by State/public entities on equipment suppliers failing to present recent tax compliance certificate
  - **No Certificate:** 100% VAT withholding
  - **Source:** [Morocco Tax 2024 Finance Law](https://auditcloud.ma/2023/12/14/tax-provisions-of-the-2024-finance-law-in-morocco/), [Morocco Corporate Tax PWC](https://taxsummaries.pwc.com/morocco/corporate/taxes-on-corporate-income)

#### Central Bank Circulars & Regulations
- **Regulatory Authority:** Bank Al-Maghrib
- **Legal Framework:** Law No. 103-12 on credit institutions and similar bodies (Royal Decree No. 1-14-193, December 24, 2014)
- **Scope:** Banks, finance companies, offshore banks, microcredit associations, payment institutions, Deposit and Management Fund, Central Guarantee Fund

- **Bank Al-Maghrib Licensing Authority:**
  - **Extended Prerogatives:** Licensing of microcredit associations and offshore banks (in addition to credit institutions)
  - **Regulation Power:** Elaboration of regulations governing activity
  - **Problem-Addressing:** License withdrawal authority
  - **Source:** [Bank Al-Maghrib Licensing](https://www.bkam.ma/en/Banking-supervision/Micro-prudential-supervision/Licensing)

- **Licensing Application Requirements:**
  - **Institution Documents:** Bye-laws, supervisory authority opinion (parent company), shareholders' agreement
  - **Capital Provider Information:** Details on capital providers, managers, directors
  - **Additional Documentation:** Bank Al-Maghrib may require further information via Circular No. 5/W/2023
  - **Licensing Models:** Bank Al-Maghrib may create licensing models for each credit institution category and/or operation type
  - **Source:** [Morocco Banking Regulation](https://www.mondaq.com/finance-and-banking/1085608/banking-regulation-comparative-guide)

- **Microfinance Regulation:**
  - **Circular No. 5/W/2023:** Relates to classification of receivables held by microfinance institutions licensed as credit establishments and coverage by provisions
  - **Prudential Rules:** MFIs bound by Bank Al-Maghrib prudential rules applicable to credit institutions
  - **Verification:** Bank Al-Maghrib verifies adequacy of administrative/accounting organization and internal control systems
  - **Financial Quality:** Ensures quality of MFI financial situation
